content:
IBuildEngine3 Interface

Definition

This interface extends IBuildEngine to provide a method allowing building project files in parallel.

In this Article

public interface IBuildEngine3 : Microsoft.Build.Framework.IBuildEngine2

Methods

BuildProjectFilesInParallel(String[],String[],IDictionary[],IList<String>[],String[],Boolean)

Allows tasks to initiate a build on a project file

public Microsoft.Build.Framework.BuildEngineResult BuildProjectFilesInParallel (string[] projectFileNames, string[] targetNames, System.Collections.IDictionary[] globalProperties, System.Collections.Generic.IList<string>[] removeGlobalProperties, string[] toolsVersion, bool returnTargetOutputs);
projectFileNames
String[]

The project to build.

targetNames
String[]

The targets in the project to build (can be null).

globalProperties
IDictionary[]

An array of IDictionary of additional global properties to apply to the child project (array entries can be null).

The keys and should both be strings.

removeGlobalProperties
IList<String>[]

A list of global properties which should be removed.

toolsVersion
String[]

A tools version recognized by the Engine that will be used during this build (can be null).

returnTargetOutputs
Boolean

Should the target outputs be returned in the BuildEngineResult.

Returns
BuildEngineResult

If the build is successful, the outputs of the specified targets are returned.

Reacquire()

Waits to reacquire control after yielding.

public void Reacquire ();

Yield()

Informs the system that this task has a long-running out-of-process component and other work can be done in the build while that work completes.

public void Yield ();

Remarks

There is only one node (msbuild.exe process) per CPU. Only one project, target, and task can build at any time on a node. If a task is waiting, for example, for a spawned tool or some other event to complete, the task can call Yield, which returns immediately. This lets the node build a target in another project, if any are available. When the task is ready to continue, it should call Reacquire. As a rough rule, if a task expects that an operation will take more than 20 or 30 seconds, it can choose to call Yield before it starts the operation, and Reaquire when the operation is complete.
